Lacy, 4 Munf. 251 THE appellants exhibited their Bill in the Superior Court of Chancery for the Richmond Bistrict, (in 1807) setting f~rtli, that the female plaintiff Mar~j was forinerly wife of Joel Tucker ancestor of the defenda~its;that she, being seized in fee in her own right of a parcel of land, called the Bowling Green, adjacent to the city of~ Richmond, consented, after much importunity from her husband Tucker, to join him in a sale of that property, hi consideration of a positive verbal agreement and promise on his part, that he would purchase other land on Shockoc hill, build thereon, and convey the same to her for the same estate she held in the Bowling Green; that she accordingly did join in the sale of the Bowling Green; and Tucker actually bought and built on a lot on Sliockoe lull containing two acres;-but died withoul settling the same on her according to his agreement. The grayer of the Bill therefore was, that time defendants should be decreed to convey the lot on Shockoe hill to *2the female plaintiff, or at least assign her dower therein. A joint answer of the adult defendants, admitted the plaintiff Mary’s title originally to the Bowling green, and the sale thereof by Joel Tucker, in which she joined; but denied the agreement alledged in the Bill, which, however, (the plaintiffs having put that fact in issue by a general replication,) was fully proved by depositions. It also appeared by exhibits, that four acres of land in Duval’s addition (the Bowling Green) were conveyed by Tucker and wife to James Thomson, for the consideration of 48Z., by deed dated June 26, 1800; and that, on 1 lie same day, Alexander M‘Rae and wife conveyed to Joel Tucker the two acres of land on Sliockoe hill, for the consideration of one thousand dollars. At September term 1809, Chancellor Tavxor dismissed the Bill as to so much thereof as prayed specific execution of the agreement, but directed the plaintiff Mary’s dower, in the lot bought of M‘Rae, to be assigned her by commissioners: and, at June term, 1813, it being admitted that her dower had been assigned in another suit, the bill was finally dismissed with costs. This Court granted the plaintiffs an appeal. Wickham for the appellants,

contended that a Court ot Equity will enforce a contract between husband and wife, founded on the consideration of her relinquishing her right to dower, or joining in a sale of her real property;— in like manner as if she were a feme sole. Itlias long been settled not to be necessary to interpose trustees, (a) The Court will set up the contract, tho’ void at law.

As to the agreement in this case, the testimony is clear; and the Statute of Frauds does not apply, the contract having been executed on one side,

Leigh contra.

The proof of the agreement, I admit, is sufficient; but the question, is, will the Court enforce it? The property of Mrs. Tucker sold for 4 8Z. only; that afterwards purchased by her husband, was ten or twenty-times its value. And that property, so much more valuable, is what she claims;—not to be paid her 48Z., with interest. Is this claim reasonable? Surely a more unreasonable one was never exhibited. The Chancellor did *3right in dismissing the bill altogether. I know of no instance of an executory contract, for a sale from husband to wife, being enforced iii equity.

Wick/tam in reply.

All contracts are executory when first made.(b) iuadeq~tacy of consideration is not sufficient to vitiate a fair contract. Besides; it appears by the record, that the husband, in the present case, had not a shilling on earth hut what he got by the wife. This circumstance repels the objection of hardship. The truth is, lie chose to lay out her money for her benefit. It is not pretended that there are any creditors; and, if there were, their claims would not be affected by any decree between these parties.
